context.text: Although the memristor as a device is new, it was conceptually postulated in 1971 by Leon Chua [6].

In 1971, Leon Chua, a professor at UC Berkeley, proposed that there should be a fourth fundamental passive circuit element to set up a mathematical relationship between \$q\$ and \$\varphi\ (F(q, \varphi)=0)\$, which he named the memristor (a portmanteau of memory and resistor) [6].
Sometimes the memristor concept is confused with various two-port networks, but basically all of such two-port networks are not memristor according to Chua's paper [6].
Chua mathematically predicted that there is a solid-state device, which defines the missing relationship between four basic variables [6].

Note that, \$M(q)={df_{{\rm M}}(q)\over dq}\$ for a charge-controlled memristor and \$W(\varphi)={dg_{{\rm M}}(\varphi)\over d\varphi}\$ for a flux-controlled memristor, where \$M(q)\$ is incremental memristance and \$W(\varphi)\$ is incremental memductance where the unit of \$M(q)\$ is Ohm and the unit of \$W(\varphi)\$ is Siemens [6].
For detailed information regarding typical \$\varphi-q\$ curves the reader is referred to [6].
Some other properties of the memristor like zero-crossing between current and voltage signals can be found in [6] and [13].
Five years after the Chua's paper on the memristor [6], he and his graduate student, Kang, published a paper defines a much broader class of systems, named memristive systems.

context.text: The scheme's noteworthy characteristics include the fol-lowing: 1) To obscure control flows, it transforms unconditional branch instructions to calls to a branch function; 2) To provide robust protection while minimizing over-head, it encrypts only the target addresses of the transformed branch instructions (note that previous encryption-based approaches [21] encrypted entire blocks of code and, as a result, incurred high performance overhead); 3) It uses constants called address obfuscation values to provide enhanced resilience to static disassembly; and 4) It employs a technique called the Random Branch Function Call (RBFC), which enables the user to control the tradeoff between the degree of tamper resistance and the overhead by modulating the frequency of integrity checks.
Code instruction obfuscation is implemented by inserting “junk bytes” into the program [13] or encrypting the instructions of the program [21].

There are several existing obfuscation methods and tamper resistance schemes that also utilize an encryption-based mechanism [21].

context.text: Spectral unmixing consists of decomposing a pixel spectrum into a collection of material spectra, usually referred to as endmembers, and estimating the corresponding proportions or abundances [4].

As reported in [4], linear spectral mixture analysis (LSMA) has often been handled as a two-step procedure: the endmember extraction step and the inversion step, respectively. in the first step of analysis, the macroscopic materials that are present in the observed scene are identified by using an endmember extraction algorithm (EEA).

According to the linear mixing model (LMM), described for instance in [4], the \$L\$-spectrum \${\bf y}_{p}=[y_{p, 1},\ldots, y_{p, L}] ^{T}\$ of the \$p\$th pixel \$(p=1,\ldots, P)\$ is assumed to be a linear combination of \$R\$ spectra \${\bf m}_{r}\$ corrupted by an additive Gaussian noise  where \${\bf m}_{r} =[m_{r, 1},\ldots, m_{r, L}] ^{T}\$ denotes the spectrum of the \$r\$th material, \$a_{p, r}\$ is the fraction of the \$r\$th material in the \${p}\$th observation, \$R\$ is the number of materials, \$L\$ is the number of available spectral bands and \$P\$ is the number of observations (pixels).
As noted in [4], dimensionality reduction is a common step of the LSMA, adopted by numerous EEAs, such as N-FINDR [9] or PPI [8].

context.text: [21] provides a comprehensive treatment of the TDOA source localization problem when the sensor positions are subject to random errors. in particular, the theoretical study in [21] indicates that the TDOA algorithms that assume perfect sensor positions would suffer from a substantial amount of performance loss when sensor position errors occur and they no longer achieve the CRLB accuracy.
To address this problem, [21] has developed a closed-form localization algorithm that takes the statistical information of the sensor position errors into account to improve performance.

In addition to localizing multiple disjoint sources, the proposed algorithm can also be applied to the special case of a single source. for single source localization, it outperforms the method of [21] in delaying the noise threshold before performance deviates suddenly from the CRLB.

Furthermore, it achieves CRLB accuracy for a source close to the sensor array in which the algorithm in [21] may not. for multiple disjoint sources, when considering only one of them is the source of interest and the others are calibration emitters at highly unreliable or even completely unknown locations, the proposed method remains to be able to exploit the calibration TDOAs to reduce the effect of sensor position errors while the one in [27] cannot.

The cost for the improvement is the estimation of sensor positions in which [21] does not require, and the simultaneous estimation of sensor and source locations in which [27] estimates them separately in sequence.
The refinement takes the similar approach in [16], [21], and [32].
Yet, a better hypothesized position closer to \${\bf u}^o_i\$ can be produced by applying the algorithm in [21] that takes the sensor position error into account.

The work in [27] presented an algorithm that uses multiple calibration emitters at known but erroneous locations to improve the source localization accuracy when sensor position errors are present.

However, its performance is much worse than the CRLB accuracy if the calibration position errors are large. in the extreme case where the calibration position errors tend to infinity (i.e., the calibration emitter positions are completely unknown), the solution in [27] would fail and become inapplicable.

The above drawbacks of the algorithm in [27] can be handled using the multiple-source localization algorithm developed here. in particular, we can consider the calibration emitters as sources at unknown locations and apply the proposed solution to estimate their positions together with the position of the unknown source of interest.

Apart from the information encapsulated in the training data, the designer should be able to mobilize the a priori information and construct constraints, which can easily be treated in the context of the set theoretic estimation philosophy [20]. for example, if the DOA of the SOI is known, and in the case where only the SOI is present with no surrounding jamming signals, it would be desirable for the system to be able to deliver distortionless response with a minimum effort, i.e., without using a training data sequence.

This framework is a generalization of the celebrated projections onto convex sets (POCS) [19], [20], [31]–[36] algorithm, which has found numerous applications for an extremely wide range of signal processing problems [20], [36]. in the POCS rationale, a finite number of closed convex constraints is available. in order for the sequence of estimates to converge, each constraint is used for an infinite number of times.
This fact is the basis for the celebrated POCS algorithm [19], [20], [31]–[36].

context.text: Beamforming design for smart antennas has become an indispensable tool for modern array applications [21]. in nowadays ultrawideband (UWB) array applications [22], beamforming imposes a variety of constraints on the array beampattern, such as nulls and distortionless constraints, in order to reject jamming signals, confront steering vector errors, poor array calibration, inoperative elements, signal wavefront distortions, source spreading, etc., [23], [24]. in the ubiquitous linear beamforming framework [21], [23], it is well-known that an \$N\$-element array has \$N-1\$ degrees of freedom (DOF), so that if \$M\$ linear constraints are imposed on the array's beampattern, then a number of \$N-1-M\$ DOF are available for the beamformer to cancel noise and interference [21].

Hence, as the number of constraints inevitably increases in nowadays applications, the designer is forced to increase the number of resources, e.g., the number of array elements or introduce time delay lines (TDL) [21], in order to effectively deal with the inescapable noise and interference.

The steering vector associated to a planar wave of wavelength \$\lambda> 0\$, which arrives to the ULA with an angle \$\theta\in[0,\pi]\$, called direction of arrival (DOA), is defined as \${\mbi s}:={\mbi s}(\theta,d,\lambda):=[1,e^{2\pi i(d)/(\lambda)\cos\theta},\ldots,e^{2\pi i(N-1) (d)/(\lambda)\cos\theta}]^t\in{\BBC}^N\$ [21].

In the classical linear ULA beamforming scenario, the beampattern is defined as the function \${\rm BP}(\theta) := {\rm BP}({\mbi s}(\theta)) := {\mbi w}^{\ast} {\mbi s}(\theta),\$ \$\forall\theta\in [0,\pi]\$, where \${\mbi w}\$ stands for the beamformer [21].

The motivation for working in a very high dimensional space \${\cal H} \times {\BBR}^{8+M}\$ is to increase the probability of having \${\rm Fix}(T)= \bigcap_{m=1}^{8+M} (K_m\cap\Pi_m)\$ nonempty, as opposed to the classical finite dimensional Euclidean space \${\BBR}^{2N}\$, where the dimension of the space itself sets a restriction on the available DOF, which are necessary for the array to combat noise and inaccuracies (see Section I). in the context of classification [2], the benefit of transferring a problem to a highly dimensional space is supported theoretically by Cover's result [2], [40], which, in simple words, states that the probability of affinely separating any two subgroups of given data approaches unity as the dimension of the space, where classification is carried out, increases. in our case, a demonstration of this will be given by the numerical examples of Section IX where the proposed design reveals the existence of a desired beamformer in the “virtual” \${\cal H}\$, for an originally infeasible problem in the standard linear beamforming frame [21], [23].

In this section, we validate the proposed design by comparing it with the classical linearly constrained minimum variance (LCMV) beamformer [21], [23]; a linear technique, which minimizes the variance of the beamformer's output subject to several beampattern constraints.
In the classical LCMV beamformer [21], [23], perfect knowledge of all the DOAs (SOI and jammers) is assumed. in this way, distortionless and null constraints can be built [21], [23].

A reproducing kernel function is positive definite,11A kernel \$\kappa\$ is called positive definite if \$\sum_{l,j=1}^L \xi_l\xi_j \kappa({\mbi x}_l,{\mbi x}_j)\geq 0,\$ \$\forall\xi_l, \xi_j\in{\BBR}\$, \$\forall {\mbi x}_l, {\mbi x}_j\in{\BBR}^m\$, and for any \$L\in{\BBZ}_{> 0}\$ [26].

Some authors call such kernels positive semidefinite. and symmetric in its arguments [26]. in addition, the Moore–Aronszajn theorem [26] guarantees that to every positive definite function \$\kappa(\cdot,\cdot):{\BBR}^m\times{\BBR}^m\rightarrow{\BBR}\$, there corresponds an RKHS \${\cal H}\$ whose reproducing kernel is \$\kappa\$ itself [26].

Such an RKHS is generated by taking first the space of all finite linear combinations \$\sum_{j}c_j\kappa({\mbi x}_j,\cdot)\$, where \$c_j\in{\BBR}\$, \${\mbi x}_j\in{\BBR}^m\$, and then complete this space by considering also all its limit points [26].

A kernel \$\kappa\$ is called positive definite if \$\sum_{l,j=1}^L \xi_l\xi_j \kappa({\mbi x}_l,{\mbi x}_j)\geq 0,\$ \$\forall\xi_l, \xi_j\in{\BBR}\$, \$\forall {\mbi x}_l, {\mbi x}_j\in{\BBR}^m\$, and for any \$L\in{\BBZ}_{> 0}\$ [26].
